content.title: Explore Isla Iguana looking for turtles

introduction.small: 300 kilometres from Panama City in the eponymous gulf, Isla Iguana has been a nature reserve since the 1980s, famous for its marine and land species, as well as the coral reef.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore Isla Iguana looking for turtles

paragraphs.text:
The white sandy beaches are visible all the way from the Punta del Tigre coastline. Separated by an arm of the Gulf of Panama, Isla Iguana and the village of Pedasì are only seven kilometres apart. A four-hour drive or a shorter plane trip will take you to this coastal town, which in itself is a gate to a large nature reserve. Scuba dive or snorkel and venture into one of the gulf's biggest coral reef, spread over 16 hectares. Swim among hundreds of marine species in crystal clear waters. Back on solid ground, a professional guide will teach you how to evolve amid tropical flora and fauna. You will thus be able to come close to and discreetly observe the five turtle species of the island, located around its heavenly beaches. Squint at the horizon line and you will see Isla Iguana, which is a yearly destination for humpback whales. Who knows, you may even spot a few!

Isla Iguana
Los Santos Province
Panamá

content.title: Dinner at the pace of Panamanian folklore at Diablicos

introduction.small: Panama is rich in history and legends. Discover a part of it while dining at Diablicos, a unique place that takes you to the heart of the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dinner at the pace of Panamanian folklore at Diablicos

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Panama City's historic district, Casco Viejo, Diablicos treats you to a typical meal. There is little risk of forgetting where you are: here, everything reminds you of Panamanian culture, from the decoration, with folkloric masks hanging on the walls, to the servers themselves, dressed in traditional garb.
Native American, Hispanic, African and Caribbean cuisine have inspired that of Panama, making it so delicious. At Diablicos, try the Ropa Vieja, made from braised beef, vegetables, peas and plantains, or the Corvina ceviche, the local fish, served in fried plantain cups. For dessert, the coconut flan will remind you of the flavours of the islands. Pair it all with a refreshing and delicious Balboa, a locally brewed beer.
During the meal, “diables”, who lend their name to the restaurant and are an integral part of the culture, begin their frenzied dance for a moment of pure folklore!

Diablicos Panamá
Al lado de la Policía de Turismo
Avenida Central 7
Panamá

+507 228 9495

www.diablicospanama.com

Dinner: around 25 PAB

content.title: The Canopy Tower, a view of the treetops

introduction.small: Life in the great outdoors in the middle of a tropical forest! Head to the Canopy Tower for an unexpected treat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Canopy Tower, a view of the treetops

paragraphs.text:
In the Soberanía National Park tropical forest, you can't miss the turquoise Canopy Tower. From its rooftop terrace, you will have the unique opportunity to observe more than 400 bird species – Panama is one of the world's hottest ornithological spots, with more than 1,000 species listed – as well as all kinds of small mammals that parade right before your eyes. You will never feel as close to wildlife, while enjoying an impressive view of the Pacific.
The Canopy Tower was originally a radar tower built by the US Air Force to help defend the Panama Canal. Converted into a hotel with 12 single rooms or suites spread over two floors, it allows you to spend one or more nights in the foliage of trees, far from the tumults of Panama City. During the day, you have unlimited access to the observation deck and organized excursions to the main observation sites.

Canopy Tower
National Park Soberanía
Panamá

+507 264 5720

www.canopytower.com

Rooms: from 229 USD

content.title: Tántalo Hotel : let go with its bohemian atmosphere

introduction.small: A lively artistic enclave in the heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tántalo Hotel : let go with its bohemian atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
Casco Viejo has many chic and trendy boutique hotels, and at the top of the pile is the very popular Tántalo Hotel. Nestled in the historic and cultural heart of Panama City, its bohemian atmosphere will charm your socks off.

Each of the 12 rooms is beautifully decorated by a local artist, in a patchwork of bold-coloured frescoes, paintings, and graffiti.

The elegant restaurant, the Kitchen, is very relaxed and creative : coconut cashew chicken ; empanadas ; fish cakes ; passion fruit tart... After enjoying the specialities of chef Pierre de Janon, climb to the superb Encina bar, on a roof decked with fairy lights.

After dark, the bar is a great place to enjoy the view and dance to the beat of the DJ sets. This is a place to see and be seen.

Hotel Tántalo
Calle 8 Este con Avenida B
Casco Viejo, Panamá

www.tantalohotel.com

Rooms: from 109 PAB

content.title: Soberanía National Park

introduction.small: Head for the green paradise of this tropical rainforest, 30 minutes from downtown Panama.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Soberanía National Park

paragraphs.text:
With 22,000 hectares of protected areas, Soberanía National Park, just 25 kilometres from the capital, provides easy access to the rainforest. This gorgeous green space is the playground of many local species, such as the howler monkey, armadillo, and the quetzal. It's a bird watcher's paradise, with over 525 species on hand. The 17-kilometre Pipeline Road provides opportunities to see roadrunners, trogons, and spangled cotingas. You can walk to the watchtower, perched 40 metres above the Panama Rainforest Discovery Center to see more tropical birds. To make the most of the atmosphere, spend a night in the park at the Canopy Tower, a former US Army radar station, now a bird-watching mecca, or the Gamboa Rainforest Resort, a vast complex immersed in the jungle.

Rainforest Discovery Center
Colon, Panamá

+507 6450 6630

www.pipelineroad.org/en

content.title: Frank Gehry's incredible Biomuseo

introduction.small: The star architect has created a museum dedicated to biodiversity in order to raise awareness of preservation issues.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Frank Gehry's incredible Biomuseo

paragraphs.text:
This odd-looking, multi-coloured, and extremely popular museum opened in 2014 at the entrance of the canal, in a former militarised zone. Like all buildings by the Canadian-American architect, to whom we owe, among others, the Guggenheim Bilbao, the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, and the Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris, its creation was a celebrated event, especially since it was and still is the first Frank Gehry building in Latin America.

The exterior is enigmatic, but the interior is pedagogical and didactic. You'll discover how, some three million years ago, the formation of the Isthmus of Panama generated climate change that caused Africa's forests to turn into savannahs. The eight rooms dedicated to biodiversity entice visitors to become aware of the need and urgency to preserve the environment. The educational approach is orchestrated brilliantly and is also great fun.

The public park outside the museum is filled with native species of trees and plants, giving visitors a sneak preview of the incredible diversity inside this eco-tourist destination.

BioMuseo
Edificio 136
Calzada de Amador
Panamá

+507 830 6700

www.biomuseopanama.org

content.title: Bristol Hotel Panama City : luxury at affordable prices

introduction.small: A colonial style hotel where refinement is at its peak.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bristol Hotel Panama City : luxury at affordable prices

paragraphs.text:
In the upscale area of the Financial District, the Bristol Panama is imbued with timeless elegance, coupled with state-of-the-art modernity, all at an unbeatable price, considering the level of luxury.

A Leading Hotels of the World member, its common areas are filled with works by local artists, while the colour palette in the 116 spacious rooms and suites is classic white, beige, and silver. The concierge service is excellent, and the hotel spa provides relaxing Panamanian treatments.

Salsipuedes, the restaurant under the leadership of TV star chef Cuquita Arias de Calvo, serves fine Panamanian cuisine in an elegant colonial setting.

Whether you come to Panama for business or vacation, enjoy the unpretentious luxury at this property, which is in one of the most exclusive neighbourhoods in the city, with easy access to all the city's main attractions.

Hôtel Bristol
Zona 10, Avenida Aquilino de la Guardia
Panamá

www.thebristol.com

Rooms: from 149 PAB

content.title: Stroll through the romantic streets of Casco Viejo

introduction.small: The historic San Felipe is an open-air museum filled with jewels of colonial architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stroll through the romantic streets of Casco Viejo

paragraphs.text:
The decrepit buildings of Casco Viejo (also known as Casco Antiguo) are gradually being rehabilitated, and each testifies to the past splendour of this colonial district built by the Spaniards.

Gentrification and the budget allocated by UNESCO to preserve the area's historical heritage have turned it into a trendy neighbourhood. Sit on the terrace in one of the cafés that line Plaza Bolivar and its beautiful 19th-century buildings, or, on Independence Square, choose a panama hat from Ecuador, just like those worn during the construction of the canal.

Be enchanted by the gilded Church of San José and the many other charming religious edifices in the neighbourhood, like the Metropolitan Cathedral and the Church and Convent of St. Francis of Assisi. Admire the facade of the Teatro Nacional, built in 1908, before moving on past the skyscrapers of the modern city to Plaza de Francia, dedicated to the 22,000 French workers who participated in the construction of the canal.

www.cascoviejo.com

content.title: Immersion in the Embera ways

introduction.small: Discover Chagres National Park and its indigenous people in the village of Parara Puru.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Immersion in the Embera ways

paragraphs.text:
The Embera indigenous community, from the province of Darien, live on the banks of the Chagres River. Of the seven tribes in Panama, they are among the most open to visitors.

As agriculture is no longer a possible source of income in this protected park, the Embara haveturned to ecotourism. Embark on a boat to reach the village of Parara Puru.

Its Noko (chief), Claudio Chami, and the villagers will welcome you in their traditional costumes, perform dances, and offer you a typical tattoo as well as some culinary specialities, while the women are sure to improvise a small craft market. While a little touristy, opening the village to foreigners is a good way for the Embera to preserve their lifestyle and ancestral traditions. You can also try your hand at tracking the 80 local animal and plant species that live in the park.

Chagres National Park
Carretera Madden
Panamá

+507 500 0855

content.title: Getaway to Portobelo Bay on the Caribbean side

introduction.small: Discover what was once the most important port in Latin America and the defensive forts of the Spanish Crown.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Getaway to Portobelo Bay on the Caribbean side

paragraphs.text:
The Bay of Portobelo and its small sleepy fishing port on the Caribbean coast, is an hour-and-a-half drive north of Panama. Located in the province of Colon, the picturesque town was once the largest Spanish port in Central America, until it became a target for pirates in the 15th and 16th centuries. Stroll among the moss-covered ruins of the Spanish fort, and then visit the Museo de la Real Aduana Portobelo, the royal treasury where the King's gold was stored.

If you're there on October 21, watch the Black Christ of the Church of San Felipe, a Nazarene Christ procession celebrated by tens of thousands of fervent pilgrims. Not far away are the shimmering colours of ‘Diablos Rojos' decked-out buses plying the chaotic roads of the province.

You can stay in El Otro Lado, a peaceful retreat in the heart of the jungle, accessible by a short boat trip. There are many diving sites in the region, among beautiful coral reefs loaded with local fish, and even a sunken B-45 plane…

content.title: Las Clementinas : for a taste of discreet charm

introduction.small: Stay in a luxurious residence in the historic district of Panama.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Las Clementinas : for a taste of discreet charm

paragraphs.text:
Here is a chic address where one is right at home.

The 1930s building once housed apartments. The original plans were maintained, resulting in rooms that are incredibly spacious. There are six suites to choose from, decorated in tropical wood parquet, palm trees, and great artwork, and three rooms, smaller but with the same attention to detail. From the picturesque balconies, the spectacle of the street unfolds before your eyes.

After visiting the cathedral and the neighbouring churches, it is a pleasure to find refuge in the ‘secret garden' of Las Clementinas, with its wooden terraces and quiet tables in the shade of old stone and tropical plants.

Located right in the historic heart of the city, a few steps from the lively Independence Square, it is very popular among locals because of its elegant restaurant and bar.

Las Clementinas
Calle 11 & Avenida B
Casco Antiguo
Panamá

+507 308 6550

www.lasclementinas.com

Rooms: from 205 PAB

content.title: Discover the fish market

introduction.small: A colourful must-see place to enjoy an ultra-fresh ceviche.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the fish market

paragraphs.text:
Breathe in the bustling energy of the city's fish market, an emblematic place frequented daily by every Panamanian family. Slalom between the stalls where freshly caught fish and shellfish are exhibited, and let yourself be transported by the noises, odours, and exotic ambience.

Open from 6:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., the atmosphere constantly changes throughout the day. Intensity is at its peak early in the morning when the fishing boats unload their goods in front of stunned visitors. Whatever the time, let yourself be tempted by some ceviche there is no better anywhere. Generally, this raw fish dish is made with corvina fish, but here they also use red snapper. The seasoning is always extremely simple: lime juice and coriander leaves, so as not to distort the flavour too much.

A small portion only costs the equivalent of about $2.50 (USD). Some cevicherias have outdoor tables and chairs if you want to settle in for full meal.

Mercado de Mariscos
Calle 15 Este
Panamá

+507 506 5741

content.title: Experience an unusual dinner at Las Bóvedas

introduction.small: Nestled at the foot of 16th-century ramparts, this restaurant-bar charms locals and visitors alike.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Experience an unusual dinner at Las Bóvedas

paragraphs.text:
Don't be afraid of ghosts ! Bóveda means jail in Spanish, and indeed, this restaurant, in the ramparts of the city, was formerly a dungeon, which held pirates, criminals, slaves, and political prisoners. Fortunately, Las Bóvedas offers a much brighter face today.

The Panama Office of Tourism renovated it in the 1980s, and today the old cells of the 300-year-old fort are thriving. Some cells are used for exhibitions, while others host a seafood restaurant.

It's a lively place, with live jazz on weekends and live music every night during the week. Sit at one of the tables on the terrace, a great place for a drink on a mild Panamanian evening.

Restaurante Las Bóvedas
Plaza de Francia
CascoAntiguo, Panamá

+507 228 8058

Menu: from 30 PAB

content.title: Savour the seafood of La Casa del Marisco

introduction.small: One of Panama's most famous fish and seafood restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Savour the seafood of La Casa del Marisco

paragraphs.text:
An institution on the local dining scene since the 1960s, La Casa del Marisco is known for its excellent fish and seafood-based cuisine, and friendly family atmosphere.

In an elegant setting behind the grey rectilinear facade and bay windows, the Acha family slips between tables laden with paella presented in earthenware dishes, plates of lobster, and crab dishes. Try the fried ceviche ; even if it is not on the menu, they will gladly prepare this specialty for you.

It is not unusual to see local celebrities here, enjoying a sea bass with salsa and green peppers, or a creamy chocolate mousse in a martini glass.

An address whose reputation exceeds the Panamanian border, thanks to John Le Carré's famous novel The Tailor of Panama, in which the protagonist feasts on lobster Thermidor in this enchanting setting.

La Casa del Marisco
Avenida Manuel Icaza
Aera Bancária, Panamá

+507 233 7755

www.lacasadelmarisco-acha.com

Menu: from 25 PAB

content.title: Lazing in the paradise archipelago of San Blas

introduction.small: This tiny island north of Panama is the ideal playground for a Robinson Crusoe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lazing in the paradise archipelago of San Blas

paragraphs.text:
Imagine 400 coral islands, mostly virgin… Only 50 are populated by the Guna, an indigenous ethnic group inhabiting their own autonomous territory, the Comarca Kuna Yala.

The lifestyle here is a thousand miles from the Panama frenzy, yet you are only a 20-minute flight from the capital, a trip that will transport you into a postcard setting of translucent waters, white sand, colourful flowers, and tropical jungle. Discover the lifestyle of the indigenous locals settled in bamboo huts, and let yourself be seduced by the pretty Molas, richly coloured fabrics characteristic of the Panamanian handicrafts made by Guna women.

Places like Yandup Island Lodge organise forest and beach excursions. The hotels offer a very different standard of comfort than the city; the real luxury lies in the landscape.

content.title: Take a boat down the canal

introduction.small: Boat on the waters of the canal and Lake Gatun, a unique trip that lets you experience the canal from the inside.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take a boat down the canal

paragraphs.text:
After watching the boats navigate through the Miraflores Locks, you will definitely want to experience this for yourself. This unusual attraction is a huge tourist draw.

Different cruise packages are available. The five-hour expedition that departs from Gamboa, the meeting point of the Chagres River and the canal, takes in Gatun Lake on the edge of the forest, with its rich flora and fauna. Very popular, too, is the shorter ferry ride that crosses the locks of Miraflores and Pedro Miguel.

You can take another ship from coast to coast, across the three systems of locks, Gatun Lake, Gaillard Cut, and under the Centennial cable bridge. This unforgettable journey takes ten hours, depending on traffic.

+507 269 9415

www.anconexpeditions.com

content.title: The Panama Canal

introduction.small: Get a behind-the-scenes look at the canal's exceptional history and construction at Miraflores Locks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Panama Canal

paragraphs.text:
Just 15 minutes from Panama City, the visitor centre at the Miraflores Locks is the most visited site in the country. Here, on four levels, you can explore the history of this extraordinary feat of engineering, through videos, photos, and scale models. You can also watch the ingenious locks in action water rushing in, giant ships gradually rising, a veritable ballet.

Between 9:00-11:00 a.m. and 3:00-5:00 p.m. traffic is at its peak. This should soon become less of an issue with the 2016 enlargement of the canal, which deals with over 12,000 ships each year.

Book a table in the panoramic restaurant to taste the specialties of the country while taking in this incredible spectacle.

Miraflores Visitors Center

+507 232 3120

www.pancanal.com

content.title: The park with the prettiest views of Panama City

introduction.small: Cerro Ancon, a verdant hill overlooking the city, offers a 360° view of the surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The park with the prettiest views of Panama City

paragraphs.text:
A well-marked road leads through the jungle to the best viewpoint of Panama. From the top of Ancon Hill, the panorama is breath-taking: great views stretch from the old quarter of the canal to the canal itself. Other viewpoints overlook the modern town, with its vertiginous skyscrapers in the background, and the red roofs of the historical district, which contrast nicely with the blue of the ocean.

The 43-hectare park also houses the administration offices of the canal. Long under US jurisdiction, control was relinquished to the country in 1999, following the signing of a treaty.

Since then, a gigantic flag flies atop the hill, recalling the historical and cultural significance of this place that now occupies a special place in the heart of Panamanians. If you decide to climb the 200-metre hill (count three quarters of an hour's walk), you may be lucky enough to cross paths with armadillos, coatis, sloths, and toucans.

Cerro Ancón
Balboa
Panamá

+507 264 7477

content.title: Enjoy the quaint atmosphere of the Vieja Habana

introduction.small: This bar immerses visitors in a delightful Cuban atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the quaint atmosphere of the Vieja Habana

paragraphs.text:
A few steps from the Presidential Guard, this Cuban restaurant draws crowds, mainly for its cocktails, which put rum in the spotlight.

Every evening, the expert bartenders prepare superb Cuba Libres, mojitos, and daiquiris, as well as other delicious beverages, under the watchful eyes of the equally expert regulars. The salsa pounds and the atmosphere warms, and soon you're beating time with your feet on the pretty cement floor tiles without even realising it.

We let ourselves quickly be carried away by the place's leisurely and festive atmosphere, which feels very Cuban. The dark panelled decor reminds one of Old Havana, as does the menu, which features typical dishes from the island.

Vieja Habana is undoubtedly the best spot to capture the Caribbean essence. A must.

Habana Vieja
Avenida B & Calle 5
CascoAntiguo, Panamá

+507 212 3873

Drinks: from 4 PAB

content.title: The American Trade Hotel : the hippest hotel in Panama

introduction.small: Symbol of the revival of Casco Viejo, the ATH will appeal to design enthusiasts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The American Trade Hotel : the hippest hotel in Panama

paragraphs.text:
This boutique hotel, opened in partnership with the ACE group, who have hotels in London, New York, and LA, is housed in a beautifully restored neoclassical building.

In 1917, the year of its construction, this was the tallest building in the country, containing a shopping centre and luxury housing. Today, the hotel symbolises the new life of the local architectural scene. Guests wander in a boho-chic setting with beautiful wood and Mexican tile floors, fabrics with palm motifs, and pleasant Italian courtyards.

The 50 rooms are elegant and sober, enhanced with a colonial touch of charm, featuring wood panelling, retro furniture and Belle Époque claw-foot bathtubs.

Besides the lively pool on the top of the building, there is a jazz bar and an elegant ground-floor restaurant with China blue cement tiles, high ceilings, and Nicaraguan furniture. A true gem.

American Trade Hotel
Plaza Herrera
Casco Viejo, Panamá

+507 211 2000

www.americantradehotel.com/index.html

Rooms: from 228 PAB

content.title: The Waldorf Astoria : a sophisticated establishment, perfect for business travellers

introduction.small: The first Waldorf to open in Latin America, this hotel appeals to business customers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Waldorf Astoria : a sophisticated establishment, perfect for business travellers

paragraphs.text:
Opened in March 2013, this hotel from the US Hilton chain is housed among the giant skyscrapers of the city centre. It has 146 rooms and private apartments, all in understated beige with subtle Panamanian touches. Those on the top floors have exceptional views.

If you are a Waldorf regular, you'll notice that the Peacock Alley Lounge is identical to that of the New York Waldorf. The property also houses the Brio, a brasserie serving French-American cuisine, and Ginger, where sushi lovers can watch the chef make their meal using only the freshest of local fish.

A swimming pool on the seventh floor has another bar, which serves excellent mojitos, along with a Jacuzzi and a solarium. A gym, spa, and business centre complete the offer of this five-star hotel in the city centre, just 15 minutes from the airport, near the business district and the vibrant Calle Uruguay, known for its evening entertainment.

Waldorf Astoria
47th St. & Uruguay Street
Panamá

+507 294 8000

www.waldorfastoria3.hilton.com/en/hotels/panama/waldorf-astoria-panama-PTYTPWA/index.html

Rooms: from 160 PAB

content.title: La Posta : for fine cuisine

introduction.small: Typical plantation architecture, tropical decor, and a talent for blending local and European flavours : no wonder La Posta is a great favourite among Panamanians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Posta : for fine cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Start with a fresh mojito at the bar before settling comfortably in front of the windows or on the terrace. The menu combines regional specialties and creative European dishes crafted with seasonal products. Adventurous eaters and lovers of raw fish will be tempted by the delicious smoked salmon salad. Try out the seafood risotto or the penne all'arrabbiata with prawns. This smart-casual restaurant, which belongs to the Henesy-Rodriguez Group, is deliciously tropical: rattan fans, brightly coloured tiles, and Latin music in the background. Market, their American-style steakhouse around the corner, is also worth a visit, especially for their Black Angus steak from the town of Chiriquí.

La Posta
Calle República de Uruguay
Bella vista, Panamá

+507 269 1076

www.lapostapanama.com

Menu: from 35 PAB
